raw_comment:
What do you notice? One thing I noticed was that the richer you are with legacy parents the more likely to get in. Essentially to have a decent shot at getting into elite colleges you need to have immense privilege. 

What do you wonder? One thing I wonder is why the poorer students are, the higher chance they have of getting in compared to wealthier non-legacy students, as well as how much of a role the “trauma essay” plays in this difference. 

How does this relate to you and your community? As someone who will apply to college soon, it makes me realize just how complicated and competitive college admissions can be. Your station in life is a huge factor in the colleges you can or can’t go to, something prevalent in students' and parents' minds as applications start and deadlines roll in.

Create a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea. “Ivy Leagues: Elite Schools or Elitists?”
ace_sentences: If a student is richer and the student has legacy parents then the student is more likely to get admitted.
A student has a decent chance to get admitted to an elite college only if the student has immense privilege.
Poorer students have a higher chance to get admitted than wealthier non-legacy students.
I wonder why poorer students have a higher chance to get admitted than wealthier non-legacy students.
I wonder how much the trauma essay affects this difference.
I will apply to college soon.
This information makes me realize that college admissions can be complicated.
This information makes me realize that college admissions can be competitive.
A student's station in life is a huge factor in the colleges that the student can go to.
A student's station in life is a huge factor in the colleges that the student cannot go to.
This factor is prevalent in the minds of students.
This factor is prevalent in the minds of parents.
The headline is: Ivy Leagues are elite schools or elitists.
